subject: Physical Fitness
title: The Sliding Filament Theory
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Sliding Filament Theory.

hook.text: In 1954, two teams independently solved how muscles contract. The answer was elegantly simple.

buildup.text: Thick filaments (myosin) and thin filaments (actin) overlap inside each muscle fiber like fingers.

discovery.text: Myosin heads grab actin and pull it inward, like rowing a rope. The filaments slide â€” the fiber shortens.

twist.text: Individual pulls are tiny â€” just 10 nanometers. Millions happening simultaneously create visible force.

climax.text: This sliding mechanism is identical in your pinky finger and a gorilla's arm. Scale differs, not design.

punchline.text: Muscles contract by sliding, not shrinking. Tiny pulls, massive power.

quiz.question: How do muscle filaments produce contraction?
options: Myosin pulls actin inward, sliding the filaments
